description: Move you camera until white dots will display in your screen. Touch at any white dots to start your learning!
Alright, biologists! Today's lesson is all about the fundamental building blocks of life
cells!  But not all cells are created equal. We'll be diving into the world of plant and
animal cells, specifically focusing on the organelles they have that set
them apart.  Let's see which organelles make each cell unique!
Both plant and animal cells share many essential organelles that work together to keep the cell functioning:
Nucleus: The brain of the cell, containing genetic information.
Cytoplasm: A jelly-like substance that fills the cell and suspends the organelles.
Cell Membrane: The outer boundary of the cell, controlling what enters and leaves.
There's another one but the animal cell don't have this part, which is the
Cell Wall: A rigid outer layer made of cellulose that provides support, protection,
and shape to the plant cell. Animal cells don't need a cell wall because they have a more flexible cell membrane.
Endoplasmic Reticulum: A network of membranes that helps with protein production and transport.
Ribosomes: Tiny factories that build proteins based on instructions from DNA.
Golgi Apparatus: Packages and distributes proteins and other materials throughout the cell.
Mitochondria: The powerhouses of the cell, converting food into usable energy
Lysosomes: The cell's cleanup crew, breaking down waste products and old cell parts.
Now, that's the similarity of the animal and plant cell when it comes to their cell parts.
But do you know plants have some more  special organelles that animal cells lack they are the
Chloroplasts: These contain chlorophyll, the green pigment that allows plants to
capture sunlight and use it for photosynthesis. Animals cannot photosynthesize, so they don't need chloroplasts.
Vacuole: A large sac that stores water, nutrients, and waste products. Plant cells
typically have one large vacuole, while animal cells may have several smaller ones.
The large vacuole in plant cells also helps to maintain turgor pressure, which keeps the plant cell rigid.
Now you can impress everyone with your knowledge of plant and animal cell organelles!
Great job listening and participating throughout this lesson!  Keep up your curiosity and love for science!
